bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Grantland Rice (1880-1954) was born in Murfreesboro, Tennessee, the son of Bolling H. and Beulah Grantland Rice. Educated at Vanderbilt University, he went to work as a reporter for the Nashville News in 1901. He also worked at Forester Magazine (1901), the Atlanta Journal (1902-1904), the Cleveland News (1905), the Nashville Tennessean (1906-1910), the New York Mail (1911-1914), and the New York Tribune (1914-1930).
In 1918 and 1919 Rice served as First Lieutenant with 115th Regiment F.A., 30th Division, U.S. Army with the American Expeditionary Force in France.

In 1930, his column "The Sportlight" became nationally syndicated and ran until his death in 1954. Rice was also the author of Songs of the Stalwart (1917), Sportlights of 1923, Sportlights of 1924, Songs of the Open (1924), and Only the Brave (1941).
On 11 April 1906, Grantland Rice was married to Katharine Hollis, and they had a daughter, Florence Davenport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Papers, 1905-1966, of Grantland Rice, are comprised of 12 cubic feet and include his Writings, Correspondence, Personal and Biographical Materials, Photographs, Subject Files, Souvenirs and Memorabilia.

physdesc.extent: 39 items include 2 typed originals, 3 copies (2 carbon, 1 photo), 1 mimeo., and 32 telegrams, 4 are addressed to Kate Hollis Rice; most have to do with selection of Football All-Americans.

462 items include 83 holograph letters, 241 typed original letters, 18 copies (12 carbon, 6 photo + retyped), 70 telegrams, 10 mimeo., printed etc., 32 greeting cards, 3 postcards, and 3 misc. 347 items are addressed to GR, 74 to Kate Hollis Rice (KHR), and 41 to other people. 3 illegible signatures, 9 incomplete signatures, 4 false signatures, 7 items unsigned.

blockquote.p: Included are 82 letters from Football All-Americans sent in connection with "This Is Your Life" radio program, December, 1948. See itemized list of these letters, and indices to outgoing and incoming correspondence, below.

did.unittitle: World war I papers - orders, passes etc.

physdesc.extent: Verse (folders 1-20), articles (21-31), radio scripts (32-35), play fragment (36-37), miscellaneous (38-Mf).

blockquote.p: See index to manuscript verse, titles and first lines, below.

Articles include the following: "Rex Beach" (17 typed pages, with corrections in pencil and ink), "New All-Timer" (on Bill Dickey)(7 typed pages, with corrections in pencil), "Pound for Pound" (on Harry Greb)(7 typed pages), "The Only Jones, or Just One Bobby" (20 typed pages, with corrections in pencil), Babe Ruth elegy (4-page typed carbon), "Sportlight" on ideal baseball team ( 2 typed pages with corrections in pencil), "Sportlight" on horse racing (2-page typed fragment), "Ex-Champions" (l-page typed fragment), Gene Tunney (7 typed pages with corrections in pencil), "The 'Umblin' Game" (on golf)(13 typed pages with corrections in pencil), "The Season As I See It" (on baseball, 1947) (5 page typed carbon with additions in pencil).

Radio scripts include interviews with Dr. Andrews (on fossils)(2-page typed fragment), Ford Bond (4 typed pages with corrections in pencil), Irvin S. Cobb (l page, typed and holograph), T.A.D. Jones (4 typed pages), Gustavus Kirby (3-page typed carbon), Ring Lardner (2 versions: 3 typed pages with corrections in pencil, 2-page fair copy, typed), Lou Little (with Ford Bond)(2 typed pages), Eddie Rickenbacker (3 typed pages), Ralph Sasse (3-page typed carbon), Al ---- (baseball statistician) (3 typed pages with corrections in pencil).
Untitled play, fragmentary (13 typed pages), has the following characters: (Act I) Rip Jones, Jenny Jones, Brink Thorn, Langdon Brown, (Act II) Marie, Babyface, Foley.

Miscellaneous manuscripts include: a short story, "The Other Man-and the Other Woman" (4 typed pages) ; football preview (2-page typed carbon); notes on post-college careers of football All-Americans (1 typed page + carbon); "Sports Parade 1933" (4-page typed list); 2-page typed list of athletes, untitled; Look's 1949 Ail-American Football Team (1-page list, typed carbon, signed by Grantland Rice, Hal Middlesworth, and Tim Gohane); 2 Sport Parade captions, "Running out an Ancient Grudge," and "The Driving Iron That Won Four Crowns" (each 1 typed page with corrections in pencil); "The Third Olympic Winter Games" (11 typed pages, numbered 12); "Questions and suggestions for All American selections" (2-page typed carbon); "Sports Parade 1934-1935" (8-page typed list)5 card index to manuscript verse (43 typed 3 x 5 cards, with titles, first lines etc).

did.unittitle: Correspondence, incoming -- letters from All-American football players

note.p: The following letters were sent to Grantland Rice c/o Ralph Edwards' "This Is Your Life" radio program when he was featured on the program in December 1948. The letters are from members of Grantland Rice's All-America football teams over a period of years. They have been removed the brown leather scrap-book initialed HGR (in which they were presented to him) and interfiled alphabetically with the rest of the incoming correspondence. Name of writer and date of letter are given below.

index.head: GRANTLAND RICE -- INDEX TO PUBLISHED VERSE (Boxes 4-8)
index.p: Includes a few poems published in places other than GR's daily columns. Index is to titles only (except in the case of untitled poems, which are entered by first line or portion thereof); when a title is followed by more than one citation in the index, this may indicate either different poems with the same title or more than one occurrence of the same poem. First number given in each case indicates box, second indicates folder.

index.head: GRANTLÁND RICE -- INDEX TO MANUSCRIPT VERSE (Box 3)
index.p: Index includes titles and first lines. All manuscript poems believed to be by GR are in box 3; numbers given are folder numbers within box 3.

indexentry.name: "Army and Navy--the Blue and the Gray--"
"As this old world goes roun' and roun'. . ."
"As long as there's a job to do"
"Back to your sheltering shadows we must turn"
"The bells of the city are ringing"
"Bill Jones had been the shining star"
"By sun and snow, by palm and pine"
"By wind and wave, by palm and pine"
"Fate called a quitter from the crowd"
"Father, Who gave but taketh back from me"
A Few Lines to Ernie Pyle
"For the thunder is back upon us"
The Forty-Eight Report, or The U.S. Goes to War
"A friend or two and a dream or two"
"Good luck is like a down hill tide"
Good Night that Means Good Bye
"(Gray) shadows gather and the wind is crying"
"He lets a few go longer than he lets the others go"
"He saw long lines of khaki form"
"Here comes the wanderer over the plain"
"Here is my traveler's cloak, dusty and torn"
"Here is the test when from down under"
"Here is your pick--from palm to fir"
"Here was the flame that flared beyond the night"
"I called them from their ancient homes"
"I give you Romance--in each crowded street"
"I have learned something well worth while"
"I saw him sprawled and broken in the mud"
"I waited for the dawn to break"
I wish I Was the Fellow
"I wonder, when you hear the north wind blowing"
"If I should ever get too old to dream"
"If it should be we will not come"
"I'm home again where the saddle's calling"
"Into your lidless eyes I stand and stare"
"It may be that in some far sky"
"It may be that tomorrow I will turn"
"It's a hell of a course, the golfer cried"
"I've piked along it for some fifty years"
"Just at the first tee,,with a sigh"
Lines on Again Looking into Keats' Lines 'On First Looking into Chapman's Homer'
Lines on the Occasion of the National Amateur Golf Championship
A Message from the Front Line
"My name is Trouble--I'm a busy bloke--"
The New King Cobra at the Bronx Park Zoo
"Night comes--and the night comes on apace"
"No one ever told me what it meant to be . . ."
"No HVelcome Home' could mean as much"
"Now all the golden harmonies are still"
The Old Cumberland's Callin', Come Home
The Old Doc with the Scythe
Past Glories 13 Peace--and the A.E.F. 13 A Philosophy 13 Prelude to Passing
The Shadow of the Fir 14 "The sheep's in the meadow"
"Some one, I thought, is singing-some loved slong"
"The song dies out--only the dream remains"
"The sun is fading in the west"
"Take, if you will, my house and lot"
"Take your fame as you find it"
"There are all the millions who are chained to desk or den"
"There are ghosts that wave and beckon"
"There is an end to every path"
"There is a test when from down under"
"There was a time I liked the brilliant glow"
"There's a road's end, mates, for every trip"
"These are my native hills that call me home"
"They do not know the starry heights of fame"
"This is the way I figure life"
"This is to make you more than merry"
"Tilt up your long, black, ugly snout"
"The time has long since drifted by"
To Billy Phelps, The Golden Boy of Yale
To Judy Howard on Her Birthday
To Mother Hollis on Her 100th Birthday
"The turmoil and the strife is done"
"We are the ones to watch someday"
We Have with Us Today after the Battle
"We know how brief the sail is"
"We who have known the rougher road"
"When I am old and April days"
"When I am old, as years are measured"
"When rain-wet crosses know the dawn that gleams"
Where the Sambier Rose is Calling
"Who are the brave? I've asked this deep in doubt"
"Who shall say when the game is done"
"Write this one passage in your Book of Strife"
"You mark them out in street or club"
"You mean a summer's day, when skies are blue"
"You thought that the south wind was sighing"

(printed dedication) This volume was born of the friendly advice, of the man who inspired it -- Grantland Rice!"

"5/8/43 To Grantland Rice - a man I have never seen but who nevertheless is responsible for anything worthwhile that this volume may contain. But for his encouragement (and reassurance), 22 years ago, I would never have been able to continue writing in the face of the apathy, indifference, and ridicule I encountered from everyone else. It is fitting that the book be dedicated to the man who made it possible, and when I return from the South Pacific (I leave in 4 days), it is my fondest hope to meet the man, personally, to v/hom the book is dedicated, -- Grantland Rice! / Wayne B. Stone, Lt. U.S.N.R.

"(Officially this book cannot be released until approved by the Navy Dept. However, in view of my recent orders to join the third amphibious Force (at my request as psychiatrist), I could not resist sending you a copy, and asking you to keep it "under cover," until you hear from me that the Navy,Dept. has approved it for distribution to service men (via the Red Cross), -- or that I am again a civilian (after the Pacific war is over), and can release it myself. W.B.S."
